content.description: Climb a featureless slab using the thumb undercling
content.location: Slab to the right of The Finger Crack

content.description: Start with a thumb press above your head and a side pull crimp with your legs spread between the adjacent wall and the massive foot hold. Span your way over to the top end of the crack and either do a large static reach or double dyno to finish.
content.protection: At least one pad. There are hidden stumps and rocks below the route so watch out for those.
content.location: Up past the upper picnic boulders

content.description: Climb up the right side of the arete
content.location: Right side of the arete to the left of Mono Arete

content.description: An easy crack with a good landing. It trends rightward, and runs hands low to a perfect fist jam up high. A good low-commitment beginner crack
content.location: On the 12ft high mezzanine rib-like wall running from the upper picnic area to the lower picnic area, find the fist crack directly in the middle between the two areas (see map photos).

content.description: A variation of bookstore blues. Start with a left on the side pull and right on a good crimp on the face. Then get feet situated and do a big move up to the top rail. From there get your feet situated and make sure to top out directly below the very top I'd say v2 is maybe v1 idk tbh felt like a really fun one to me tho.
content.location: Start a little above bookstore blues.

content.description: With hands set left in crack and right in mono fire to the top
content.location: Start with left hand in the crack and right hand in mono
The Arete to the left of One Way

content.description: Low start. Bear hug the double arete up.
Start high on edges and hike your hands through long moves to reach the top
content.location: Boulder directly left of Crystal Method Slab

content.description: Climb the slab by mantling on flexible flake
content.location: To the left of Thumbdercling Slab

content.description:
Small crack that works up the middle of the boulder. 

  Hard feet placement.
content.protection: crash pad for big move at the end

content.description: Climb up and left with the sharp arete.
content.location: short arete on SE corner of boulder closest to parking.

content.description: Climb this steep slab using the small/sharp crystals
content.location: Slabby face directly behind the Finger Crack boulder

content.description: Begin from a seated position, follow the arete up and right to the top of the arete
content.location: The arete directly across from The Right Way

content.description: Start left hand on the arete with a good thumb catch and right hand on a crimp. Use small feet to reach up to the rail and then an easy traverse right to top out center of the boulder.
content.location: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MQqgezt3atcCould be considered upper picnic but it is pretty far back and on the other side of the trail from the front range.

content.description: Within a canyon separating the Junebug boulder from its left neighbor is a fun, hidden beginner finger crack. Same basic quality and difficulty as the tennis shoe crack down front, but this will be a less busy. For a newer partner, the opportunity to leave the problem by stemming the canyon may make it feel less exposed and committing.
content.location: Walk around to the left side of Junebug boulder and squeeze into the little cave there. It opens into a narrow canyon. The crack is on the immediate left side.

content.description: Mostly beginner stuff, all but one below v3 and mostly v1's. The single v6 is just a dyno.
